title: Georgian-Style Townhouse Listed in West London for £3.65 Million
text:
A West London townhouse once owned by Oscar-winning set designer Carolyn Scott is on the market for £3.65 million (US$4.7 million.)

The recently refurbished Georgian-style house was listed Wednesday by Debbie McFadyen of Finlay Brewer.

According to property records, the house was last sold in 2007 for £1.53 million. The current owner is “a former music executive,” according to Finlay Brewer and public records.

The owner could not be reached for comment.

Ms. McFadyen said that Ms. Scott, who won an Academy Award for best art direction for the film 1994 “The Madness of King George,” lived in the house up until 2007. The current owner, she added, is moving to a country house in Dorset.

More: Dubai Looks to Expo 2020 to Reinvigorate Its Property Market

The three-story house has an expansive walled garden with a brick patio and a pizza oven, a lawn with Egyptian Anubis sculptures and off-street parking. It has five bedrooms, three bathrooms, a conservatory-style dining room and a reception/entertaining room with an original fireplace and floor-to-ceiling shuttered sash windows.

Ms. McFadyen said that unlike typical Victorian townhouses, this home is flooded with natural light from wide windows and still retains many of its period details, including exposed brickwork in the hallway.

The garden, she added, “is magical.”

From Penta Mark Rothko’s ‘Blue Over Red’ Could Top $25 Million

The 3,400-square-foot home is on a corner plot at Goldhawk and Wingate roads in Brackenbury Village, a residential district whose properties date from the 1860s to about 1890.

“Brackenbury is a wonderful village with a center that has little shops, including a dry cleaners and a butcher shop,” Ms. McFadyen said. “It has a real sense of community. It has access to airports and parks and has great schools.”
